Name: Hunting
Description: Majority of a group's nutritional intake comes from terrestrial animal resources

Name: Gathering
Description: Majority of a group's nutritional intake comes from terrestrial plant resources

Name: Fishing (aquatic)
Description: Majority of a group's nutritional intake comes from aquatic resources

Name: Normal
Description: Normal HGF group: at time of contact, subsistence was based exclusively on hunting, gathering and/or fishing. No domesticated resources were exploited, except perhas the dog or plant substance such as tobacco.

Name: Suspect
Description: Suspect: altrough the group may be organized similarly to hunter-gatherer-fishers, some subsistence may come from exchanges with non-HGF groups

Name: Mobile
Description: Group is mobile and moves entire population from camp to camp as they go about the subsistence round

Name: Sedentary
Description: Group is completely sedentary or group moves into and out of a central location that is maintained for more than one year

Name: Nuclear, limited polygyny
Description: Independent nuclear families with occasional or limited polygyny

Name: Polygyny, atypical cowives pattern
Description: Independent polygynous families, unusual co-wives pattern (either polygyny is preferentially sororal, with cowives in separate quarters or it is typically non-sororal, with cowives in same quarters

Name: Polygyny, typical cowives pattern
Description: Independent polygynous families, usual co-wives pattern (either polygyny is preferentially sororal, with cowives in same quarters, OR typically non-sororal, with cowives in separate quarters)

Name: Minimal extended
Description: Minimal extended or "stem" families, i.e., those consisting of only two related families of procreation (disregarding polygamous unions), particularly of adjacent generations

Name: Small extended
Description: Small extended families, i.e., those normally embracing the families of procreation of only one individual in the senior generation but of at least two in the next generation. Such families usually dissolve on the death of the head

Name: Large extended
Description: Large extended families, i.e., corporate aggregations of smaller family units occupying a single dwelling or a number of adjacent dwellings and normally embracing the families of procreation of at least two siblings or cousins in each of at least two adjacent generations

Name: Limited polygyny
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny occasional or limited

Name: Polygyny, sororal cohabit
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny common and preferentially sororal, and co-wives not reported to occupy separate quarters

Name: Polygyny, sororal separate
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny common and preferentially sororal, and co-wives typically occupying separate quarters

Name: Polygyny, non-sororal cohabit
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny general and not reported to be preferentially sororal, and co-wives typically occupying separate quarters

Name: Polygyny, non-sororal separate
Description: Polygynous, with polygyny general and not reported to be preferentially sororal, and co-wives not reported to occupy separate quarters

Name: Local autonomy with leader
Description: Local autonomy with performance-based leadership, leaders are acknowledged

Name: Local autonomy with leader and council
Description: Local autonomy with a formal council and a leader who assembles the council and has other group duties

Name: Regional leaders
Description: Neighbourhoods of villages/settlements/large camps integrated into an overarching leadership and decision making organization

Name: Autonomous, matrix of similar HG groups
Description: Group is autonomous and exists in a matrix of similarly scaled hunter-gatherer systems

Name: Autonomous, articulated to more complex HG group(s)
Description: Group is autonomous but is articularted to a socially or politically more complex group of hunter-gatherers

Name: Articulated to a non-HG society
Description: Group exists in a culturally heterogeneous region and is articulated to a non-hunter gatherer society, either mutualistically or in a patron-client relationship

Name: Absence of distinctions
Description: Absence of any significant class distinctions

Name: Dual: hereditary aristocracy and lower class
Description: Dual stratification into a hereditary aristocracy and a lower class of ordinary people

Name: No subsistence relief; some assistants
Description: No relief from subsistence and no special dress prerogatives, but messengers as regular assistants

Name: No subsistence relief; some assistants and dress
Description: No relief from subsistence and only minor dress prerogatives, but both messengers and a talking chief or speaker for the leader

Name: Some subsistence relief
Description: Some regular relief from subsistence, in-kind contributions to the leader from the "people," sometimes special roles for the leader's wife

Name: Complete subsistence relief; assistants, distinctive dress
Description: Complete relief from subsistence duties, more assistants, special roles associated with the leader, visible symbols associated with the office, perhaps a permanent "guard," perhaps special marriage rules, and very distinctive clothing

Name: Host's residence
Description: Rituals and ceremonies held in host's residence

Name: Dance or Men's house and Sweat lodge
Description: Dance house or men's house, and sweat house

Name: No ownership, use rights recognized
Description: No ownership reported, use rights recognized by others

Name: Grp ownership, hh claim trees/similar features
Description: Local group claims exclusive use rights over resource location, residential sites, while households may claim special trees and similar features of the landscape

Name: Grp ownership, subgrps claim excl. access to resources
Description: Local group claims for hunting areas, dominant animals, fishing sites, and animal drive locations, such claims administered by group leader, but smaller segments may claim exclusive access to resource locations

Name: Elite ownership
Description: Elite ownership of land and resources
